topic_name: Filesystem mount and unmount;; Hard links vs symbolic link ; /Proc Filesystem, /NFS, /CIFS mount, Sparsebundle filesystem

questions.question: A system administrator needs to create a backup script that will continue to work even if a file is moved to a different directory on the same filesystem. Which linking approach should they use and why?
options: Hard links, because they reference the inode directly and remain valid regardless of the file's path
Symbolic links, because they are more flexible and can span across filesystems
Hard links, because they take up less disk space than symbolic links
Symbolic links, because they automatically update when the target file is moved
questions.explanation: Hard links point directly to the inode, so they remain valid even if the original filename/path changes. Symbolic links would break if the target file is moved since they reference the path, not the inode.

questions.question: When would mounting a filesystem with the 'noexec' option be most appropriate from a security perspective?
options: When mounting a read-only filesystem to prevent any modifications
When mounting a temporary filesystem like /tmp to prevent execution of potentially malicious uploaded files
When mounting network filesystems to improve performance
When mounting the root filesystem to prevent system corruption
questions.explanation: The 'noexec' option prevents execution of binaries from that mount point. This is particularly useful for directories like /tmp where users might upload or create files, preventing execution of potentially malicious code while still allowing file storage.

questions.question: A developer is troubleshooting a process and needs to examine its current working directory, open file descriptors, and environment variables. Which filesystem would provide this information most effectively?
options: The /sys filesystem, as it contains all system information
The /proc filesystem, specifically under /proc/[PID]/ directories
The /dev filesystem, where device information is stored
The mounted NFS filesystem where process data is cached
questions.explanation: The /proc filesystem provides a virtual interface to kernel data structures, including detailed process information under /proc/[PID]/ such as cwd (current working directory), fd/ (file descriptors), and environ (environment variables).

questions.question: An organization needs to share files between Linux and Windows systems while maintaining proper file permissions and supporting large files over 4GB. Which mounting solution would be most appropriate?
options: CIFS mount with SMB3 protocol, as it supports large files and cross-platform permissions
NFS mount, as it's specifically designed for Windows-Linux interoperability
Local hard links, as they work across different operating systems
Sparsebundle filesystem, as it's optimized for mixed-platform environments
questions.explanation: CIFS (Common Internet File System) with SMB3 protocol is designed for Windows-Linux file sharing, supports files larger than 4GB, and can handle cross-platform permissions. NFS is primarily Unix/Linux-oriented, and sparsebundle is mainly a macOS technology.

questions.question: A Time Machine backup on macOS appears to be using less disk space than the actual data being backed up. What filesystem characteristic explains this behavior?
options: Hard links are being used to avoid duplicating unchanged files between backups
The backup is compressed using built-in filesystem compression
Sparsebundle filesystem allocates disk space only as needed, not reserving the full backup size upfront
Symbolic links are pointing to original files instead of copying them
questions.explanation: Sparsebundle filesystems (used by Time Machine) are sparse disk images that only allocate actual disk space as data is written, rather than reserving the entire declared size immediately. This allows efficient storage utilization for backups.
